children.subject: Thanksgiving is late November. Couldn’t we have online for the remainder? It’s pretty much dead week and finals, and exams have to be virtual anyway to accomodate those who chose the online option.

I'm not so sure about this. They would probably want to avoid conflicting with Summer Sessions, which ends on August 14, and classes start less than two weeks after that, on August 26. Even moving the start of the semester up a week to August 19 doesn't pull the end of the semester out of December (much less before Thanksgiving) unless they shorten the semester.
This would also be highly inconsiderate to this who are interning over the summer and are working until mid-late August. Having classes overlap with a full-time internship would not be fun.
UCSD has already released a hybrid schedule for fall. I think if they can, so can berkeley.
UCSD start latter than us, it's a quarter school I believe. Also, just because they have a hybrid schedule doesn't mean they've worked out all the logistics on how to implement one.

I'm not sure Berkeley would even be prepared for a hybrid setting next semester by late August. We are much larger than private schools and may need some time to work out things like classroom and building capacity reduction to comply with health guidelines. Not to mention all classes need to prepare a way to support remote students.

It is due to corona. My parents are professors in the UNC system, and they’re being told to prepare for the same thing. They want the students to not leave campus to minimize risk of getting infection elsewhere. 

Even NYU is opening in the fall.

Also, what would be the goal of this? If anything, it would seem more reasonable to push it back (kinda hard with the winter holidays though), because that would increase the odds of there being a vaccine/Corona becoming less of an issue. Or is this a thing independent of Corona?

While Berkeley is a public school and hence partly funded by the public (i.e. the state of California), we are actually more dependent on students coming in in fall. Many private schools have large endowments stemming from alumni donations and other investments that give them some leeway in terms of student enrollment. Berkeley, on the other hand, does not have such significant resources. Hence, it is even more vital for our school that people do actually enroll, both over summer and in the fall, because the University will lose a significant source of revenue otherwise.

As a matter of fact, this whole situation becomes even worse considering the fact that the Big Give was planned for this year, where the University was planning on raising substantial funds to invest in infrastructure etc. However, due to the pandemic, this did not work out as expected. Hence, we ended up with less revenues than expected due to less enrollment, refunds on housing, etc., and a substantially reduced effect from the Big Give. Hence, the situation is actually quite the opposite from what you described.

Wouldn't Berkeley save on wages if we're entirely online? For instance, staffing reception desks and physical maintenance could be scaled down significantly. Given that wage standard in Berkeley is high, I think the campus can save a significant amount if it's entirely online. Moreover, unlike private school, a larger chunk of Berkeley tuition is payed by international students, who might be more inclined towards online given the hassle of travel restrictions and potentially getting quarantined at customs every time.

@Anon Calc - you mean Berkeley will go on to cut jobs and remove staff? I am not okay with the job cuts !!! What will those staff do then ? Till date there have no massive layoffs in Berkeley even though they might have taken a hit on their budget.  We cannot be thinking of benefiting our situation at the cost of someone else's jobs!!!

The reality is, even non-tenured professors are at risk and not just staffs. The university simply cannot maintain the cost of every position currently as they've already lost so much from sports and housing.  They'll need to cut costs somewhere or they'll not survive and online is an obvious way to scale down operational costs.

Well there's also an economic standpoint as well. Universities want to have their services fully running and the full experience available to students. And I've heard a lot of incoming students planning to defer if possible and other students willing to take a gap semester. Universities are going to lose a lot of money either way, and is probably the reason why Berkeley isn't willing to budge on any tuition reductions. I don't think it's possible to make Berkeley start and end the semester early because of the overlap with summer session, as someone else already mentioned.

I believe that most of the schools that announced that they will offer in-person classes are mainly the ones that are private or financially tuition dependent institutions. I also believe that Berkeley (and other UCs as well) also gets their funds from state taxes and government funds, as it is a public state school (correct me if I'm wrong). So we might afford to have fully online classes, while losing some students? But every university is going to take a hit either way, whether that's spending more money on medical precautions to protect students, or losing tuition income from dropped out students, or even both. An online only option probably comes with the least risk. Let me know if there are any other opinions.

history.content: Is this something berkeley can do as well? Is this an option currently being considered? It seems pretty reasonable to me, especially giving the students an option to stay home as well.
history.subject: Notre Dame and U of SC have moved Fall earlier, ending before Thanksgiving
